column1: After eating, I will wash the dishes.	Después de comer, lavaré los platos.	"

column1: After washing my hands, I will eat.	Después de lavar mis manos, voy a comer.	"

column3: Combination of ""Después"" (from Late Latin ""de ex post"" - ""of that (which comes) next"") indicating succession in time or place, and ""de"" (from Latin ""de,"" indicating origin, separation, or derivation).

A commonly utilized structure to indicate future or intent, this phrase is made by conjugating the verb ""Ir"" (to go) with the appropriate personal pronoun (in this case, ""yo"" - I), followed by ""a"" (to). The infinitive form of the main action verb follows immediately after.
Root verb ""Comer"", derived from Latin ""comedere"", meaning to eat or consume. In the ""Voy a"" structure, the verb is in the infinitive and indicates a future action Single sentences preferable."

column1: After you clean the kitchen, then you can go to the park.	Después de que limpies la cocina, entonces puedes ir al parque.	"

column2: Compound word meaning ""after"" in the context of sequence or order. ""Después"" on its own can denote ""after"" in terms of time or space. Both ""de"" and ""que"" are derived from their Latin equivalents ""de"" and ""qui"".

column3: root verb ""limpiar,"" meaning to clean. Like many Spanish words, the root verb ""limpiar"" originates from Latin ""limpiare"" which had a similar meaning - to make bright, to clear.

column2: ""La"", a definite singular female article meaning ""the,"" used here before the female noun ""cocina,"" meaning ""kitchen."" Both ""la"" and ""cocina"" stem from Latin ""illa"" and ""coquina"" respectively.

column1: You must put on your coat before going outside.  	Debes ponerte el abrigo antes de salir afuera.	"

column1: The next day, after lunch, she called.	Al día siguiente, después del almuerzo, ella llamó.	"
**Al día siguiente**: Time phrase inclusive of article, noun, and adverb,
column2: corresponds to ""the next day"". Phrase comprised of ""Al"" (combination of ""a,"" preposition meaning ""to"" and ""el,"" the [masculine] definite article), ""día"" (masculine noun meaning ""day""), and ""siguiente"" (adjective or adverb describes something that follows or comes after, derived from the verb ""seguir,"" to follow).
means ""after the"". Phrase comprised of ""Después"" (adverb or preposition, from late Latin ""de ex post,"" meaning ""after"") and ""del"" (apocopated form of the preposition ""de el"": ""of the"").
signifies lunch. Typically the most substantial meal of the day in Spanish-speaking countries, consumed around midday or early afternoon.
translates to ""she"", referring to the subject.

column1: **Llamó**: Verb, 3rd person singular, simple past tense
column2: means ""she called"". Derived from the infinitive verb ""llamar"", which comes from Latin ""clamare"", meaning to shout or call out. The simple past tense typically indicates an action completed at a fixed point in the past."
